context: First meeting with Maya Torres at her garage

lines.text: Torres Garage. The sign is hand-painted, faded by years of sun and salt air. Through the open bay door, you can hear the sharp crack of a ratchet and the low hum of a radio.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: You lost? This isn't a parking lot.
She doesn't look up from the engine she's working on. Grease-stained hands, focused eyes, zero patience for small talk.

choices.text: I heard you're the best mechanic in Nova Pacifica.
My car needs work. I've got cash.
Nice garage. You run this place alone?

lines.label: maya_responds_flattery
lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Flattery doesn't pay the bills. But... you're not wrong. What're you driving?
She finally looks up. Her eyes scan your car through the garage door — and you can see the exact moment she catalogs every problem with it.

lines.label: maya_responds_business
lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Cash talks. Pull it in, let me take a look.
She wipes her hands on a shop rag and walks toward the bay door. All business.
Something flickers across her face — there and gone. She turns away, but her shoulders relax just slightly.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: So. You here for a reason or just sightseeing?

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Okay look. It's not hopeless. The bones are there. Barely. But the intake is shot, and I wouldn't trust those brakes past 40. Let me see what I can do.
She's already rolling under the car before you can answer. You hear her muttering — half to herself, half to the engine, like she's having a conversation with it.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: This one's on the house. But next time? You're paying. And you better not wreck my work.
